title: 108_hr5403
content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to provide detailed reporting of nursing expenditures, including wages and benefits for nursing staff by staff level. The Secretary will redesign cost reports to meet this requirement. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates reporting of nursing expenditures by staff level. The Secretary will redesign cost reports to comply with this requirement and develop quality measures in consultation with experts and stakeholders. Quality measures for a payment system under the Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 will be developed in consultation with experts and stakeholders. These measures will include process, structural, and outcome measures that are valid, reliable, and structured for data collection. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires new technologies to have outcome measures that are risk-adjusted, valid, reliable, and structured for data collection. It also mandates including a quality measure for nursing home staffing and making provisions for small skilled nursing facilities. It also requires a quality measure for nursing home staffing and provisions for small skilled nursing facilities. The Secretary will develop and test methods for linking payment rates under this section to quality, in consultation with various healthcare organizations and experts. These methods will tie a portion of a provider's payment to their performance on quality indicators measured under subsection (f). The Secretary will develop and test methods to link payment rates to quality indicators for skilled nursing facilities, including special payments for those with higher direct care staffing. Testing will be done through pilot studies and other appropriate methods, with a deadline for completion in line with recommended timelines. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, including an analysis of Medicare's cross-subsidization, industry margins, current trends' impact on costs, demographic changes, and options for addressing payment issues. The Secretary will provide annual and final reports to Congress on the impact of current trends, staffing shortages, demographic changes, and options for financing quality long-term care services, including nursing home care, over the next five decades. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress within 5 years of the enactment of the Act. The report will include results of a study on the impact of amendments on care quality in skilled nursing facilities, recommendations for changes to the Medicare payment system for enhanced quality, and an analysis of alternative approaches to address identified issues.
